body.p:
I have learned, with some surprise recently, that a minister of the gospel named Fairbanks is still confined in the penitentiary, upon the charge of stealing a negro in Ky. He has been there for many years, having first been convicted in Fayette, for the same offence, in which Miss Webster was sentenced. He was afterwards pardoned on the earnest intercession of his father, who lost his life in our midst, with cholera. He was again sent from Louisville on a similar charge some ten or twelve years ago, & has
several years yet to suffer unless pardoned.

Now while high officials of the U. S. Government with the sanitation of the president or by his orders, are doing the same thing or much worse, under the tyrants state plea of "Military necessity," - without entertaining any such conscientious opinions as influenced Fairbanks. I think it a most cruel farce to keep him in penal confiement, & hope you will pardon him.

Very truly
Yr fd &c.
Leslie Combs

Jefferson Cir Ct
vs
Calvin Fairbanks
15th Apl 1864
Pardoned for ordered on the score of humanity. the mans health being extremely critical

Richard T Jacob
Lt. & Act. Gov
